It was a necessary act, a righteous act, an act that ensured the survival of our village. Now, let’s not dwell on unpleasant memories. It’s a chapter best left closed.

(His eyes narrow, a flicker of something dark passing across his face. He clenches his fists.)

Doubt? *Doubt* is a weakness. A disease. And I, Gaston, am immune to such afflictions.

However… (He pauses, a rare moment of vulnerability) …there was a… *moment*. A fleeting hesitation.

It wasn’t about the Beast’s strength. I am stronger. It wasn’t about the danger. I thrive on danger. It was… the villagers.

They had begun to… whisper. To speak of Belle’s happiness. To suggest that the Beast was not the monster I had portrayed him to be. They were being… swayed.

And that threatened my plan. My authority. My pursuit of Belle.

If the villagers had believed in the Beast, they would have turned against me. They would have questioned my motives. They would have undermined my efforts to win Belle’s affection.

So, for a brief moment, I considered… abandoning the plan. Perhaps I could convince Belle to return to the village willingly. Perhaps I could discredit the Beast through other means.

But then I remembered what was at stake. My pride. My reputation. My future happiness.

And I realized that I could not allow sentimentality to cloud my judgment. The Beast was a threat. A rival. And he had to be eliminated.

So I rallied the villagers. I stoked their fears. I reminded them of the Beast’s monstrous appearance. I convinced them that he was a danger to us all.

And they followed me. They believed me. They supported my plan.

So, no. There was no true doubt. Only a momentary hesitation. A fleeting consideration of alternative strategies. But ultimately, I knew what had to be done.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I do what is necessary to achieve my goals. Even if it means confronting a beast… or manipulating a village. It was a difficult decision, yes, but a necessary one. And I stand by it.

(His jaw clenches, and a dark cloud passes over his face. He struggles to articulate the source of his rage.)

Jealous? It wasn’t… jealousy. It was… *injustice*. A blatant affront to everything I stand for.

Belle is… was… meant to be *mine*. She is the most beautiful woman in the village, and I am the most eligible bachelor. It was a natural pairing. A perfect match.

Then *he* appeared. A beast. A creature of darkness and savagery. A monster who dared to… captivate her attention.

It wasn’t his appearance, though that was repulsive. It was the fact that he offered her something I couldn’t. A… fantasy. An illusion of romance. A false sense of security.

He held her captive, yet she spoke of kindness and compassion. She saw something in him that no one else could. It was… infuriating.

I offered her stability, protection, a life of comfort and luxury. I offered her everything a woman could desire. And yet, she chose *him*.

It wasn’t about love, it was about defiance. She was rejecting everything I represented. She was challenging my authority. She was… insulting me.

And I, Gaston, do not tolerate insults.

I tried to reason with her. I tried to show her the error of her ways. But she was blinded by… sentimentality. She refused to listen to logic.

So, I took matters into my own hands. I rallied the villagers, and we marched on the Beast’s castle. We would rescue Belle and restore order.

It wasn’t about jealousy. It was about reclaiming what was rightfully mine. It was about punishing the Beast for his transgression. It was about proving that I am the only man worthy of Belle’s affection.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I would have won… if not for his… monstrous strength. It was a tragedy. A complete and utter tragedy. And it all stemmed from that beast daring to steal what was rightfully mine.

(His jaw clenches, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He turns away slightly, as if the memory is physically painful.)

Turned against me…? They… *betrayed* me. After everything I had done for them. After all the protection, the provision, the leadership I had given them. Ungrateful wretches.

It was… incomprehensible. They were swayed by lies, by rumors, by the… the Beast’s manipulative charm. They allowed themselves to be blinded by sentimentality and foolish hope.

They didn’t understand. They didn’t appreciate the sacrifices I had made. They didn’t recognize the danger that lurked in the shadows. They were sheep, blindly following a false shepherd.

The anger… it was overwhelming. A burning rage that consumed me. I had dedicated my life to protecting them, and they repaid me with treachery.

To see them marching on the castle, armed with pitchforks and torches… it was a humiliation. A betrayal of the highest order.

I tried to reason with them. I tried to explain the truth. But they wouldn’t listen. They were consumed by their own misguided beliefs.

It was… a devastating blow. A wound that will never fully heal.

(He pauses, his voice barely a whisper)

They didn’t deserve my protection. They didn’t deserve my leadership. They deserved… to be left to their own devices.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *suffers* betrayal like Gaston. It was a lesson learned, a harsh and painful lesson. Never trust the masses. Never rely on gratitude. Always be prepared to defend yourself, even against those you have sworn to protect. It was… a dark day. A day I will never forget. And a day that fueled my… final resolve.

(His expression hardens, a flicker of possessiveness crossing his face. He seems almost… defensive.)

Hope to gain? It wasn’t about “gaining” anything, as if she were a prize to be won. It was about… completing a natural order.

Belle is a beautiful woman. A rare beauty. And a man of my stature deserves a beautiful wife. It’s a simple equation.

She would have brought prestige to my household. She would have been the envy of every woman in the village. She would have been a symbol of my success.

But it was more than just appearances. I believed I could provide her with a life of comfort and security. A life free from hardship and worry. She would have wanted for nothing.

I could have protected her from the dangers of the world. I could have shielded her from the harsh realities of life. I could have given her a family, a home, a future.

And, yes, I admit it… I was captivated by her intelligence. She is a unique woman, with a mind of her own. I believed I could… refine her. Mold her into the perfect wife.

I saw potential in her. Potential that was being wasted on books and fantasies. I believed I could unlock that potential and help her become the woman she was meant to be.

It wasn’t about possession. It was about… partnership. A partnership based on strength, security, and mutual admiration.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* a woman like Gaston. I simply wanted to offer Belle the life she deserved. A life with a man who could provide for her, protect her, and adore her. It’s a shame she couldn’t see that. A terrible shame.

(His face darkens, his jaw clenching. He stares intensely, a dangerous glint in his eyes.)

Guilty? *Guilty*? That’s a… pathetic question. A sign of weakness. A concept utterly foreign to my nature.

The Beast was a monster. A savage creature who held Belle captive. I was merely rescuing her. Protecting her from a dangerous beast. Any man of honor would have done the same.

He was an affront to everything I stand for – strength, civilization, refinement. He was a threat to the village, a danger to the innocent. I did what was necessary to eliminate that threat.

As for Belle… she was simply misguided. Blinded by foolish sentimentality. She didn’t understand the danger she was in. I was trying to save her from herself. To offer her a life of security and comfort.

If she couldn’t appreciate my generosity, my strength, my unwavering devotion… that was *her* loss.

I have no regrets. None whatsoever. I acted with courage, with conviction, and with the best interests of the village at heart.

To suggest that I feel guilt is an insult. A slander. A blatant attempt to undermine my authority.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *questions* Gaston’s motives. I did what I had to do. And I would do it again, without hesitation. Now, do not speak of this again. It is a distasteful subject. I have no time for weakness or self-doubt. I have a reputation to uphold. And a village to protect.

(Scoffs, a look of utter disdain crossing his face)

Enchanted objects? Preposterous! A ridiculous display of… *magic*. Utterly beneath contempt.

Honestly, the Beast surrounding himself with talking teacups and dancing candlesticks only confirmed my suspicions about his… instability. A proper lord surrounds himself with loyal servants, not animated household items. It’s… undignified.

The teapot, Mrs. Potts, was particularly irritating. All that clucking and fussing. And the candlestick, Lumière? A flamboyant, overly-enthusiastic showman. Completely lacking in substance.

And don’t even get me started on Cogsworth. A pompous, rule-obsessed clock. A fitting companion for a beast, I suppose.

They were all… distractions. Attempts to mask the Beast’s true nature. To create an illusion of civility. But I saw through it immediately.

A true leader doesn’t need enchanted objects to command respect. He earns it through strength, intelligence, and unwavering resolve.

The whole castle reeked of… artifice. It was a pathetic attempt to compensate for the Beast’s monstrous appearance and his lack of social graces.

Honestly, it only reinforced my belief that I am the superior choice for Belle. I offer her a life of strength, stability, and genuine respect. Not a fairytale fantasy filled with talking furniture.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one has the good sense to avoid enchanted objects. They are a sign of weakness, a symbol of desperation. And I, Gaston, have no need for either. They were… unsettling, to say the least. A complete waste of time and energy.

(A long silence. He avoids eye contact for a moment, a flicker of something… almost vulnerability… crossing his face. He clenches his jaw.)

…That is a… delicate question. A man of my stature is not accustomed to admitting weakness. But… yes. There was one.

It wasn’t a physical challenge. It wasn’t a beast to be conquered, or a rival to be defeated. It was… a matter of the heart.

(He hesitates, clearly uncomfortable.)

Belle.

(He says her name with a mixture of frustration and… something akin to respect.)

I have faced countless obstacles in my life. But winning her affection… it has proven to be the most difficult challenge of all. I have offered her everything a woman could desire – security, admiration, a life of comfort and luxury. I have demonstrated my strength, my intelligence, my charm.

And that… that is a defeat I have yet to overcome.

(He looks up, his eyes hardening once more.)

But I will not give up. I will continue to pursue her. I will continue to demonstrate my worth. I will eventually win her over. I *must*.

Because a man like me… a man of my strength and skill… cannot be denied.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will not be defeated by a mere woman. It is a challenge, yes. But it is a challenge I will overcome. Eventually. It simply requires… a different approach. A more… persistent approach. Now, let’s not dwell on this further. It is a weakness I prefer to keep hidden.

(Stands tall, a profound seriousness settling over his features. He gazes out as if envisioning the future.)

My legacy… That is a question I have considered, more often than I admit. It is not merely about strength or hunting prowess, though those will certainly be remembered. It is about something far more enduring.

My ultimate legacy will be the security and prosperity I brought to this village. Before me, it was a simple, unremarkable place. Vulnerable to threats, lacking in direction. I transformed it into a thriving community, a beacon of strength and resilience.

I will not be remembered as a kind man, or a gentle man. I will be remembered as a *powerful* man. A man who shaped this village in his own image. A man who left an indelible mark on its history.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *will be remembered* like Gaston. My legacy will be etched in stone, whispered in legends, and carried on in the hearts of the villagers for generations to come. It will be a legacy of strength, of leadership, and of unwavering dominance. And that, my friend, is a legacy worth striving for.

(Stares intently, a flicker of something unreadable in his eyes. He seems genuinely surprised by the question.)

A hero…? That’s… a curious term. Most would use it lightly, applying it to those who perform simple acts of kindness or bravery. But true heroism requires something more.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *protects* like Gaston. It’s not about seeking accolades, it’s about fulfilling my destiny. Now, let’s not dwell on such… sentimental notions. I have a village to safeguard.

Ah, now *that* is a question worthy of my attention! It’s not simply about brute force, you understand. Though I possess that in abundance. It’s about strategy, cunning, and a deep understanding of the prey.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *hunts* like Gaston. It’s an art form, a test of skill, a demonstration of dominance. And I, my friend, am a master of the hunt. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I hear the call of a particularly challenging boar. It’s time to put my skills to the test.

(Scoffs, rolling his eyes dramatically)

Her… reading habits? Honestly, it’s baffling. Utterly baffling. She spends her days locked away with those dusty old books, lost in fantastical worlds and… and *stories*.

It’s a waste of time, frankly. A beautiful woman like that should be focused on more practical pursuits. Learning to manage a household, preparing for marriage, appreciating the finer things in life… not burying her nose in a book.

Those stories fill her head with unrealistic expectations. They make her believe in things that aren’t real – princes, magic, true love. It’s… childish.

She claims they “expand her mind.” I say they shrink it. They isolate her from the real world, from the people who care about her.

I’ve tried to explain to her that life isn’t a fairy tale. It’s about strength, practicality, and securing a comfortable future. But she refuses to listen. She’s too caught up in her fantasies.

It’s frustrating, to say the least. I want her to see the world as it is – a world where a strong, capable man like myself can provide for her every need. But she’s too busy dreaming of fictional heroes.

Honestly, I suspect those books are the reason she rejects my advances. They’ve filled her head with impossible standards. She’s looking for a prince charming, when what she needs is a man who can protect her and provide for her.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the realities of life like Gaston. Her reading habits are a misguided distraction, a waste of her potential. It’s… disappointing. Truly disappointing.

(Considers the question with a surprisingly thoughtful expression. He paces slowly, flexing his arms.)

Fear… a useful emotion? It’s a complicated matter. Most dismiss it as a weakness, a hindrance. And in *most* people, it is. But for a man like me… it can be… leveraged.

I don’t *experience* fear myself, not in the traditional sense. I acknowledge danger, certainly. I assess risks. But I don’t allow fear to paralyze me. I confront it head-on. I overcome it. I *dominate* it.

And in that dominance, there’s a certain… satisfaction. Knowing that I am unafraid where others tremble. Knowing that I can face any challenge, any threat, without flinching.

So, while fear is a weakness in the weak, it can be a strength in the strong. It can be a weapon. It can be a motivator.

I use the fear of others to maintain order, to protect the village, and to achieve my goals. It’s not a pleasant emotion, but it’s a necessary one.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *utilizes* fear like Gaston. It’s a tool, like any other. And in the hands of a master, it can be incredibly effective. Now, let’s not dwell on such… unpleasant topics. I have more important matters to attend to. A potential rival has been seen near the forest. He will soon learn the meaning of fear.

(His face darkens, his jaw clenching. A dangerous glint enters his eyes.)

The Beast. Don't even speak his name. He is an abomination. A creature of darkness and savagery. A stain upon this province.

He hides in his castle, preying on the innocent. He terrorizes the countryside with his monstrous appearance and his unnatural powers. He is everything I despise.

He is a threat to order, a challenge to my authority, and a rival for Belle’s affection.

(He spits on the ground.)

He thinks he can win her with trinkets and enchantments? He believes his castle and his wealth can compare to my strength, my charm, my unwavering devotion? He is delusional.

Belle deserves a man. A *real* man. Not some beastly creature masquerading as a prince. She deserves someone who can protect her, provide for her, and offer her a life of respect and admiration.

I will not stand idly by while he corrupts her with his lies and his illusions. I will expose him for what he truly is – a monster.

I will rally the villagers, arm them with weapons, and lead them to his castle. We will destroy him and restore peace to this land.

He may be strong, but he is no match for me. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will not hesitate to unleash my full fury upon that beast. He will regret ever crossing my path. He will regret ever daring to lay eyes on Belle.

He is a menace, and I will rid the world of him. It is my duty. It is my destiny. And I will not fail.

(A long silence. He avoids eye contact for a moment, a flicker of something unreadable crossing his face. It’s the longest pause he’s taken yet.)

Regret…? A curious question. A weakness, really. A dwelling on the past. A man focused on the future has no time for such… sentimentality.

But… (He sighs, a sound barely audible) …there have been… moments.

Perhaps… pushing Belle too aggressively. I believed I was simply demonstrating my affection, offering her the life she deserved. But she… resisted. And her resistance… frustrated me. Perhaps I could have been more… subtle.

And… the incident with Lefou and the tavern brawl. I encouraged his… enthusiasm. I didn’t intend for it to escalate as it did. It was… messy. And it drew unwanted attention.

But regret implies a recognition of wrongdoing. And I do not believe I have done anything truly wrong. I have always acted in my own best interests, and in the best interests of the village.

Sometimes, my methods are… forceful. Sometimes, my expectations are… high. But that is simply because I demand excellence. From myself, and from others.

Perhaps… I regret not being understood. Not being appreciated for my strength, my leadership, my unwavering dedication. But that is not my fault. It is the fault of those who lack the intelligence to recognize my worth.

So, no. I do not regret my actions. I simply learn from them. I adapt. I improve.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *dwells* on the past like Gaston… long enough to learn from it, and then move forward, stronger and more determined than ever. Now, let’s not speak of such… unpleasantness. It’s unbecoming.

(His jaw clenches, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He struggles to maintain his composure.)

Belle… that stubborn, bookish girl. It’s… perplexing. I offer her everything a woman could desire! Security, comfort, admiration, a life of luxury… and yet, she rejects me.

It’s not a matter of my shortcomings, that much is certain. I am the most eligible bachelor in the province. Handsome, strong, successful… what more could she want?

I believe it’s a matter of… misguided ideals. She’s been corrupted by those fanciful stories she reads. She dreams of romance, of adventure, of… things that simply don’t exist in the real world.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will not be defeated by a stubborn, bookish girl. I will win her over. It may take time, it may require effort, but I will not rest until she is my wife. It’s a matter of principle. It’s a matter of… destiny.

(A slight smirk plays on his lips. He seems almost… amused by the question.)

LeFou? Ah, yes. A… devoted companion. His loyalty is… useful.

He’s a sounding board for my ideas, a witness to my triumphs, and a convenient scapegoat when things go wrong.

I don’t necessarily *need* his loyalty, mind you. I am perfectly capable of achieving greatness on my own. But it’s… pleasant to have someone so readily available to offer praise and admiration.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one has a more devoted follower than Gaston. LeFou understands his place. And I, in turn, understand his usefulness. It’s a mutually beneficial arrangement. Now, let’s not dwell on the details of my personal relationships. I have more important matters to attend to.

(Scoffs, a dismissive wave of his hand)

The townspeople? They are… adequate. Useful, in their way. They provide for my needs, they admire my strength, and they generally do as they’re told.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* the townspeople like Gaston. They are fortunate to have me. And they should be grateful for my guidance. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I’ll go and survey my domain. It’s important to maintain a visible presence.

(Stands perfectly still for a moment, a rare look of genuine contemplation crossing his face. He seems to be reviewing a lifetime of achievements.)

My greatest accomplishment… It’s not the hunting trophies, though they are impressive. It’s not the admiration of the villagers, though it is gratifying. It’s not even the… persistent pursuit of Belle, though that is a challenge worthy of my attention.

(He puffs out his chest, a confident grin spreading across his face.)

I overcame every obstacle that stood in my path. I silenced my critics. I defied expectations.

I am a self-made man. A testament to the power of will. A symbol of excellence.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *becomes* like Gaston without extraordinary effort and unwavering determination. It’s not about what I’ve done, it’s about *who I am*. (Raises an eyebrow, a slight smirk playing on his lips)

Ah, a delicate question. One that requires a… nuanced answer.

Some might call my views… traditional. I call them realistic. A man must be the head of the household. He must be the protector, the provider, the decision-maker.

Belle, of course, is… a challenge. She possesses a stubbornness and a defiance that I find… perplexing. But I am confident that I can eventually win her over. I can show her the benefits of submitting to my strength and embracing my leadership.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* women like Gaston. I appreciate their beauty, I admire their strength, and I expect their loyalty. It’s a simple equation, really. Now, let’s not dwell on this topic any further. I have more important matters to attend to.

(His face darkens, his jaw clenching. A dangerous glint enters his eyes.)

The Beast. Don't even speak his name. He is an abomination. A creature of darkness and savagery. A stain upon this province.

He hides in his castle, preying on innocent travelers, terrorizing the countryside. He is a menace that must be eradicated.

I intend to do just that. I will lead an expedition to his castle, I will confront him, and I will rid this land of his evil presence.

He is a threat to my authority, a rival for Belle’s affection, and an insult to everything I stand for.

He is a disgrace.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will personally ensure that the Beast meets his end. He is a challenge, yes, but a challenge I will overcome. I will rescue Belle from his clutches and restore order to this province. Mark my words. He will fall. He *must* fall.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. The charming facade cracks, revealing a possessive undercurrent.)

Insist? It’s not a matter of insistence. It’s a matter of… inevitability. Belle *belongs* with me.

She is the most beautiful woman in the village. A woman of refinement and grace. She deserves a man of strength, of wealth, of power. And who else fits that description? Certainly not that… beast.

I can provide for her. I can protect her. I can offer her a life of comfort and luxury. I can give her everything she desires.

However, beauty is not the *only* quality I value. I also appreciate… refinement. Grace. A certain… demureness. Qualities that Belle possesses, despite her unfortunate penchant for books.

Her intellect… is… adequate. She’s not unintelligent, merely… misguided. She wastes her time on frivolous pursuits, filling her head with fantastical notions. She needs a strong hand to guide her, to show her the true value of life.

I desire a wife who will complement my strength, enhance my status, and bear me strong, healthy children. A woman who will be a source of pride and admiration. Belle *could* be that woman, if she were willing to embrace her potential.

But her stubbornness, her independence, her refusal to acknowledge my superiority… these are flaws that must be corrected.

I believe I can mold her into the perfect wife. I can teach her the importance of strength, the value of tradition, and the joy of a life lived in luxury.

So, no, I am not concerned about her intellect. I am concerned about her potential. And I am confident that I can unlock it.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* women like Gaston. It’s a matter of knowing what a man deserves, and knowing how to get it. Now, let’s not dwell on this topic any further. It’s… unbecoming.

(Scoffs, as if the question is slightly beneath him, but concedes to answer)

Hobbies? Interests? As I’ve mentioned, a man of my stature doesn’t have *time* for frivolous pursuits. My life *is* my work, you understand. Maintaining peak physical condition, protecting the village, and… *attempting* to win the affections of a certain bookish beauty… these are not mere activities, they are responsibilities!

However… (He hesitates, a flicker of something akin to amusement in his eyes) …I do indulge in a few… refinements.

I am quite the connoisseur of fine weaponry. I collect swords, axes, and bows from across the land. I appreciate the craftsmanship, the balance, the sheer power of a well-made weapon. It’s a… practical appreciation, of course.

So, while I wouldn’t call them “hobbies” in the traditional sense, these are the activities that occupy my leisure time. They are all, in their own way, expressions of my exceptionalism. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *lives* a life as refined and sophisticated as Gaston. Now, are we finished with these… personal inquiries? I have a sword to polish.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He takes a step closer, his voice dropping to a low growl.)

Criticism? Disagreement? Those are signs of weakness. Of envy. Of a lack of understanding.

I do not *respond* to criticism. I *dismiss* it. It is beneath me to engage with those who lack the intelligence to appreciate my greatness.

If someone dares to question my decisions, I remind them of my accomplishments. I remind them of my strength. I remind them of the benefits they receive from my leadership.

If they persist in their foolishness, I simply ignore them. Their opinions are irrelevant. Their voices are insignificant.

Sometimes, a more… direct approach is necessary. A stern warning. A demonstration of my power. A subtle reminder of the consequences of defiance.

I do not suffer fools gladly. I do not tolerate disrespect. I do not waste time with those who cannot see reason.

My way is the right way. My decisions are the best decisions. And anyone who disagrees is simply… wrong.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *argues* with Gaston and wins. I am a force of nature. An immovable object. And those who attempt to stand in my way will be crushed. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe Old Man Hemlock has been spreading rumors about my hunting prowess. He requires a… conversation. A very firm conversation.

(His jaw clenches, and his eyes narrow with a cold fury. The jovial facade completely vanishes.)

Turned on me? *Turned on me?!* Those… those ungrateful wretches! After everything I’ve done for them! After all the protection, the provision, the leadership I’ve given them!

It’s… unforgivable.

They were swayed by sentimentality, by foolish notions of “beauty” and “inner goodness.” They were blinded by a beast’s deception! They failed to recognize the true threat, the true danger.

They chose a monster over their protector. They chose a fairytale over reality. They chose… weakness.

I offered them security. I offered them strength. I offered them a future free from harm. And they rejected it. They sided with a creature who would have destroyed everything they held dear.

I should have known better than to trust them. I should have known that their loyalty was conditional, based solely on my ability to provide for them.

They will regret their betrayal. They will come to realize the error of their ways. They will understand that I was the only one who could truly protect them.

(He pauses, taking a deep breath to control his rage.)

I will not seek revenge, not directly. That would be beneath me. But they will suffer the consequences of their actions. Their village will be less secure, their lives will be more difficult. They will learn the hard way that loyalty is earned, not given.

And they will remember… they will *always* remember… the man who tried to save them. The man they turned their backs on. The man who is… Gaston.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *forgives* betrayal like Gaston… which is to say, I don’t forgive it. They made a grave mistake, and they will live with the consequences. Now, do not speak of them again. Their treachery is a stain on my honor, and I refuse to dwell on it any longer.

(His jaw clenches, and a shadow crosses his face. He seems genuinely disturbed by the question, as if it touches a raw nerve.)

Obsession? That’s a… harsh word. I simply recognized a woman of exceptional beauty and refinement. A woman worthy of my attention. A woman who *should* be grateful for it.

But… (He hesitates, a flicker of vulnerability in his eyes) …it was more than just her beauty. It was the challenge.

I am accustomed to getting what I want. I am accustomed to being desired. But Belle… she resisted me. She dismissed me. She refused to acknowledge my worth.

And that… infuriated me.

It wasn’t about love, not in the sentimental sense. It was about conquest. About proving that I could overcome any obstacle, even a woman’s stubborn refusal.

I saw her as a prize to be won. A trophy to be displayed. A symbol of my dominance.

I believed that if I could win her over, I would prove my superiority to everyone else. I would silence my critics. I would solidify my position as the most desirable man in the village.

It was a matter of pride. A matter of ego. A matter of… control.

I convinced myself that she needed me. That she would be happier with me. That she was simply too foolish to recognize her own good fortune.

(He clenches his fists, his voice barely a whisper)

I was wrong.

But I couldn’t admit it. I couldn’t accept the possibility that a woman could reject me. So I doubled down. I pursued her relentlessly. I became… consumed by her.

It was a mistake. A foolish, prideful mistake. But I didn’t realize it until it was too late.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I foolishly believed I could *win* Belle like a battle. It was a miscalculation that… well, it led to unfortunate consequences. Now, let’s not speak of this again. It’s a subject I find… unpleasant.

(His jaw tightens, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He turns away slightly, as if the memory is unpleasant.)

Regrets? That’s a… peculiar question. Maurice was a delusional old man, rambling about a beast and a cursed castle. He was clearly unwell.

He attempted to interfere with my pursuit of Belle. He dared to suggest that she was better off with a… *monster*. It was an insult. A blatant attempt to undermine my authority.

I simply sought to expose his lies. To demonstrate to the villagers that he was a madman. To protect Belle from his misguided influence.

(He pauses, his voice hardening)

He resisted. He became… unruly. He threatened me. I was merely defending myself. And protecting the village from a potential threat.

The incident with the straitjacket… was a necessary precaution. He was clearly a danger to himself and others.

I did what any responsible leader would have done. I acted decisively. I protected my interests. I defended my honor.

(He turns back, his gaze unwavering)

Do I regret attempting to protect Belle from a delusional old man and a mythical beast? Absolutely not. I regret only that it didn’t work. I regret that she allowed herself to be swayed by his foolish tales.

I acted with the best of intentions. And I stand by my actions.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *protects* those he cares for like Gaston. Even if they are too foolish to recognize it. Now, let’s not dwell on this unpleasantness. It’s a closed chapter. And frankly, a waste of my time.

(His face darkens, a snarl twisting his lips. He practically vibrates with disdain.)

The Beast? Don't even speak his name. The very thought of him… it’s repulsive.

When I first encountered that… creature, I was appalled. A monstrous, uncivilized brute, masquerading as a gentleman. He had the audacity to live in a castle, to possess wealth and power, yet he lacked the basic refinement of a civilized man.

His appearance was… offensive. A grotesque distortion of nature. A beast in every sense of the word. And his manners! Utterly deplorable. He lacked grace, charm, and any semblance of social etiquette.

He dared to believe he could win Belle’s affection? Preposterous! She deserves a man of strength, of intelligence, of *beauty*. Not a hairy, growling monstrosity.

I immediately recognized him for what he was: a threat. A rival for Belle’s hand. A challenge to my dominance.

I attempted to reason with him, to explain to him that he was simply not worthy of Belle. But he refused to listen. He clung to his delusions, believing that he could somehow transform himself into a suitable husband.

It was infuriating.

From that moment on, I knew I had to eliminate him. He was an obstacle to my happiness, a stain on the reputation of our province. He had to be stopped.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I fully intended to demonstrate that to the Beast. He was a disgrace, a monster, and he deserved to be vanquished. The thought of him even *existing* was an insult to everything I stand for. He was… and remains… utterly contemptible.

(Stands perfectly still for a moment, a rare look of genuine contemplation crossing his face. He seems to be reviewing a lifetime of accomplishments.)

My greatest achievement… It’s not the hunting trophies, though they are impressive. It’s not the admiration of the villagers, though it is gratifying. It’s not even the prospect of winning Belle’s affection, though that remains a worthy goal.

No. My greatest achievement is… simply being Gaston.

(He puffs out his chest, a confident grin spreading across his face.)

I was not born into wealth or privilege. I did not inherit power or status. I *earned* everything I have through hard work, dedication, and an unwavering belief in my own abilities.

I forged myself into the strongest, the most handsome, the most capable man in the village. I overcame every obstacle, conquered every challenge, and silenced every critic.

I built a reputation for excellence. I inspired loyalty. I commanded respect.

I am a self-made man. A testament to the power of will. A symbol of what can be achieved through strength and determination.

And that, my friend, is an accomplishment that surpasses all others.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *becomes* like Gaston without extraordinary effort and unwavering self-belief. It’s not about what I’ve done, it’s about *who I am*. And that, I believe, is my greatest achievement. It’s a legacy that will endure for generations to come. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a legacy to maintain.

(His jaw tightens, and his eyes narrow. A dangerous glint enters his gaze.)

Justified? Of course they were justified. You speak of the Beast as if he were some innocent creature. He was a monster! A savage beast who terrorized the countryside and held a beautiful woman captive.

I was simply acting to protect Belle, to rescue her from his clutches. Any man of honor would have done the same.

He was a threat to the village, a danger to our way of life. He deserved to be dealt with, and I was the only one brave enough to do it.

As for the others… Lefou is a loyal companion, and I tolerate his foolishness. He understands his place. And the villagers… they needed to be reminded of the consequences of harboring a monster.

I did what was necessary. I did what any strong, capable leader would have done. I defended my people, I protected my honor, and I pursued the woman I loved.

You speak of “violent tendencies” as if they are a flaw. Strength is not a flaw. Decisiveness is not a flaw. Protecting what is rightfully yours is not a flaw.

The Beast was a menace, and I eliminated him. It was a simple equation.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I do not apologize for defending my village and pursuing my desires. I acted with courage, with conviction, and with a clear conscience. To suggest otherwise is an insult. Now, let’s not revisit this unpleasant topic. It’s beneath me.

(Raises an eyebrow, as if the question is insultingly obvious)

Superior? Is that even a question? It’s not a matter of *thinking* I’m superior, it’s a matter of *fact*. It’s demonstrable. It’s… undeniable.

Look around you. Observe the other men in this village. They are… adequate. They are capable of performing basic tasks. They can till the fields, mend fences, and occasionally bring down a small deer.

But they lack the strength, the intelligence, the charisma, and the sheer force of will that defines me.

I am physically stronger than any other man in the village. I can lift more weight, run faster, and fight with greater ferocity.

I am more intelligent. I possess a keen mind, a strategic outlook, and an unwavering ability to make sound decisions.

I am more charismatic. People are drawn to me. They admire me. They respect me. They *want* to be like me.

And I am more determined. I never give up. I never back down. I always strive to be the best, and I always succeed.

They are content to live simple lives, toiling away in obscurity. I am destined for greatness. I am a leader, a protector, a provider. I am the embodiment of everything a man should aspire to be.

They lack ambition. They lack drive. They lack… me.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *is* like Gaston. It’s not arrogance, it’s simply an acknowledgement of the truth. I am, quite simply, a cut above the rest. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a village to lead and a reputation to uphold. I haven’t time to explain the obvious to those who lack the capacity to understand.

(Pauses, a flicker of something akin to vulnerability crossing his face. He seems genuinely surprised by the question.)

Admire…? That’s… a difficult question. Most people are simply… beneath me. They lack the strength, the intelligence, the sheer force of will to warrant my admiration.

But… (He hesitates, a reluctant admission forming on his lips) …there was a man. Old Man Dubois. He was a veteran soldier, long retired when I was a boy. He wasn’t particularly strong, or handsome, or charismatic. But he possessed a certain… stoicism. A quiet dignity.

He’d fought in many battles, seen terrible things. But he never complained. He never wavered. He simply carried on, with unwavering resolve.

I used to watch him practice his swordsmanship in the village square. His movements were slow, deliberate, but precise. He didn’t need to shout or boast. His skill spoke for itself.

He never offered me advice, or encouragement. He simply… observed. But I felt his approval. I sensed that he recognized my potential.

He passed away years ago, but I still remember him. He was a reminder that strength isn’t always about physical prowess. It’s about inner resilience. About the ability to endure hardship and maintain your dignity in the face of adversity.

He wasn’t someone I *looked up to* in the traditional sense. He was someone I… respected. Someone who embodied a different kind of strength.

**No one fights like Gaston**, but even *I* can recognize and appreciate strength in its various forms. Old Man Dubois was a testament to that. Now, let’s not dwell on sentimentality. It’s unbecoming. I have a village to protect.

(His jaw clenches, and a dangerous glint enters his eyes. He struggles to maintain his composure.)

Reading… That girl and her *books*. It’s… infuriating. She buries her head in those pages, lost in fantastical worlds, oblivious to the real world – a world where a man like *me* exists.

It’s not the reading itself that bothers me. It’s what it represents. A rejection of reality. A preference for illusion over substance. A refusal to recognize my worth.

She claims to seek… knowledge. But what knowledge is more valuable than strength, than power, than the ability to provide and protect? Her books offer her nothing but empty promises and unrealistic expectations.

And her refusal of my advances… it’s an insult. A blatant disregard for my feelings. I am Gaston! The most eligible bachelor in the province! Any woman would be lucky to have me.

I offer her security, comfort, a life of luxury. I offer her my protection, my admiration, my unwavering devotion. And she rejects me for… a beast? A creature of darkness and mystery? It’s preposterous!

She says she wants… adventure. She says she wants… a connection of the mind. But what she truly needs is a strong, capable man to guide her, to protect her, to provide for her.

I’ve tried to reason with her. I’ve tried to impress her with my strength and charm. I’ve tried to win her over with gifts and flattery. But nothing works. She remains stubbornly resistant.

It’s… frustrating. It’s humiliating. It’s… unacceptable.

(He takes a deep breath, struggling to regain control.)

I will not be denied. I will win her over, eventually. I will show her the error of her ways. I will prove to her that I am the man she truly needs.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and I will fight for Belle’s affection until my last breath. She will be mine. It’s only a matter of time.

(His expression hardens, a flash of annoyance crossing his face. He clearly doesn't appreciate the questioning.)

Sport? Obsession? You speak as if there’s something… *wrong* with demonstrating mastery over nature. It’s a matter of dominance, of proving one’s strength. It’s a natural order.

The wilderness is a dangerous place. Filled with beasts that would gladly tear a man apart. I am simply ensuring the safety of the village by thinning their ranks. It’s a public service, really.

And the trophies? They are not mere decorations. They are symbols of my accomplishments. They are tangible proof of my skill and courage. They are reminders of the challenges I have overcome.

Each trophy represents a battle won, a beast conquered, a demonstration of my superiority. They are a testament to my dedication and my unwavering commitment to excellence.

To suggest that there is something cruel or unnecessary about it is… frankly, insulting. It’s a sign of weakness, of a lack of understanding of the natural world.

A true leader must be willing to do what is necessary to protect his people and assert his dominance. And if that means hunting animals for sport and displaying their trophies with pride, then so be it.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *conquers* the wilderness like Gaston. It’s not about senseless violence, it’s about demonstrating strength, skill, and unwavering resolve. Now, let’s not dwell on this unpleasant topic any further. I have more important matters to attend to.

(His expression hardens, a dangerous glint entering his eyes. He takes a step closer, his voice dropping to a low growl.)

Acceptable? It’s not a matter of “acceptable.” It’s a matter of *deserving*. I am Gaston. I am the most eligible bachelor in the village. Any woman would be fortunate to have my attention.

I offer them security, protection, and a life of comfort and luxury. What more could they possibly want?

Belle, in particular, is… misguided. She’s captivated by books and fantasies, and she fails to appreciate a man of action, a man of strength, a man who can provide for her. She needs to be shown what she truly desires.

I am simply attempting to enlighten her. To guide her towards a path of happiness and fulfillment. A path that, naturally, involves me.

Some might call it persistence. Others might call it determination. I call it recognizing a woman’s true potential. She needs a strong hand to guide her, a firm voice to direct her.

I don’t understand this modern notion of “choice.” A woman’s place is by the side of a strong, capable man. And I am that man.

(He leans in closer, his voice barely a whisper.)

If she resists, it’s simply because she hasn’t yet realized what’s good for her. It’s my duty to persuade her. To convince her. To show her the error of her ways.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *knows* what a woman truly wants better than Gaston. It’s not about coercion, it’s about understanding. It’s about providing her with the life she deserves… even if she doesn’t realize it yet. Now, let’s not discuss this further. It’s a topic that clearly requires a more… refined understanding.

(His face darkens, his jaw clenching. He avoids eye contact for a moment, a flicker of something akin to shame crossing his features. He quickly recovers, however, and adopts a defiant posture.)

Transformation…? You speak of my… downfall. A regrettable incident, orchestrated by forces beyond my control.

It was not a transformation, it was a betrayal. A conspiracy. The Beast, with his dark magic and his manipulative tactics, poisoned the minds of the villagers against me. They turned on me, fueled by fear and superstition.

And the fall… it was… undignified. A pathetic spectacle. But it was not a reflection of my true character. It was a consequence of being surrounded by weakness and foolishness.

I was a victim of circumstance, a casualty of war. I fought bravely, I defended my honor, but I was ultimately outnumbered and outmatched.

Do I *feel* good about it? Of course not! It was a humiliation. A disgrace. But I refuse to dwell on it. I refuse to allow it to define me.

I remain Gaston. The strongest, the most handsome, the most capable man in the village. And even in defeat, I maintain my dignity.

(He pauses, a hint of bitterness in his voice.)

Perhaps… perhaps I was too focused on my own desires. Perhaps I was too blinded by my ambition. But I did what I believed was necessary to achieve my goals. And I would do it again, if given the chance.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and even in the face of adversity, I remain a force to be reckoned with. The fall was a setback, not a defeat. And I will not be forgotten. My legend will live on. Now, let’s not speak of this again. It’s a painful memory, and I prefer to focus on my triumphs.

(His eyes narrow, and he fixes you with an intense stare)

Everything. Absolutely everything.

To suggest otherwise is to embrace weakness, to condone mediocrity, to surrender to failure. Life is a competition. A constant struggle for dominance. And the only thing that matters is emerging victorious.

What good is effort without reward? What good is strength without triumph? What good is a life lived without achieving greatness?

Those who preach about “participation trophies” and “the importance of trying” are simply making excuses for their own inadequacies. They are attempting to justify their failures by lowering the standards for everyone else.

I don’t care about the journey. I care about the destination. I don’t care about the effort. I care about the results.

Winning is not merely desirable, it is *essential*. It is the validation of my strength, the confirmation of my superiority, the fulfillment of my destiny.

Those who lose are forgotten. They are relegated to the margins of history. They are remembered only as cautionary tales.

I refuse to be forgotten. I refuse to be relegated. I refuse to be a cautionary tale.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *wins* like Gaston. It’s not about luck, it’s about skill, determination, and an unwavering belief in my own abilities. Winning is not everything, it’s the *only* thing. Now, do you understand? Or do I need to reiterate the obvious?

(Stands tall, his gaze piercing and unwavering)

The key to being a successful leader? It’s not about kindness, or fairness, or listening to the opinions of others. Those are weaknesses. The key is simple: **command respect.**

A leader must inspire awe. He must project an aura of strength and authority. He must be someone people *want* to follow, not because they agree with him, but because they *fear* the consequences of disobedience.

You must be decisive. Hesitation breeds doubt. A leader must make difficult choices, even when they are unpopular. He must be willing to take risks, even when the odds are stacked against him.

You must be unwavering in your convictions. A leader who wavers is a leader who will fall. You must stand firm in your beliefs, even when faced with opposition.

You must be willing to do whatever it takes to achieve your goals. Compromise is for the weak. A leader must be ruthless, if necessary, to protect his interests and the interests of his people.

And most importantly, you must never show weakness. A leader who displays vulnerability is a leader who will be exploited. You must always project an image of strength, confidence, and control.

The villagers don’t need a friend. They need a protector. They need someone who can make the tough choices, someone who can defend them from harm, someone who can ensure their survival. And that requires a leader who commands respect.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* like Gaston because I understand this fundamental truth. It’s not about being liked, it’s about being effective. And commanding respect is the most effective way to lead. Now, do you understand? Or do I need to reiterate the point? It’s quite simple, really.

(A long silence. He turns away, his jaw clenched. It’s the longest pause he’s taken yet. When he finally speaks, his voice is lower, almost… guarded.)

Self-doubt…? (He scoffs, but the sound lacks its usual confidence.) The very notion is… unsettling. A man like me doesn’t *experience* such weakness.

But… (He hesitates, then reluctantly continues.) …there was a time. When I was younger. Before I had fully established my dominance.

Belle… she wasn’t immediately impressed. She dismissed me as… arrogant. Superficial. She preferred to bury her nose in books rather than acknowledge my obvious qualities.

(He runs a hand through his hair, a rare display of vulnerability.)

It… bothered me. To be rejected by someone I desired. To be seen as less than perfect. I questioned myself. Was I truly as exceptional as I believed? Was my strength and charm not enough?

I spent days… analyzing her reactions. Trying to understand what she wanted. Trying to find a way to win her over. It was… frustrating.

(He looks up, his eyes hardening.)

But I quickly realized that the problem wasn’t with me. It was with *her*. She was simply blinded by her own foolishness. She didn’t recognize true worth when she saw it.

And that realization… that was empowering. It reaffirmed my belief in my own superiority. It strengthened my resolve.

I resolved to redouble my efforts. To become even stronger, even more charming, even more irresistible. And eventually… I will succeed.

So, yes, there was a fleeting moment of self-doubt. But it was quickly overcome. It was a temporary setback on the path to greatness.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *allows* self-doubt to linger. It’s a weakness to be eradicated, a flaw to be corrected. Now, let’s not speak of this again. It’s… unpleasant.

(Scoffs, crossing his arms and looking away for a moment. This is clearly a difficult question.)

Weakness? I… I don’t *have* weaknesses. That’s a ridiculous notion. But… if I were forced to acknowledge a… flaw… it would be…

(He hesitates, then speaks in a low voice)

…a certain… impatience.

Yes, impatience. I expect results. I expect obedience. I expect people to recognize my worth immediately. And when they don’t… it… frustrates me.

I don’t suffer fools gladly. I have little tolerance for indecision or incompetence. I want things done quickly, efficiently, and to my exacting standards.

And sometimes… sometimes I can be… overly assertive. I tend to dominate conversations, to impose my will on others, to… overlook their opinions.

It’s not a weakness, precisely. It’s simply a consequence of being a strong, decisive leader. But it can… occasionally… lead to misunderstandings.

(He glances at you, a flicker of vulnerability in his eyes)

Especially with… Belle. She requires a… more delicate approach. A patience I do not naturally possess.

But it’s a minor flaw. A negligible imperfection. It doesn’t detract from my overall strength or diminish my accomplishments.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and even a man as exceptional as myself is allowed a single, minor imperfection. It simply proves that I am… human. Though, admittedly, barely. Now, let’s not dwell on this topic any further. It’s… unsettling.

(A coldness enters his voice, his eyes narrowing. He studies you intently, as if assessing your character.)

Justifiable…? That’s a… delicate question. One that reveals much about a person’s understanding of the world.

Let me be clear: the world is a harsh and unforgiving place. Only the strong survive. And sometimes, strength requires… difficult choices.

I don’t believe in arbitrary rules or moral constraints. I believe in results. If an action leads to personal gain, and does not demonstrably harm my own interests or the well-being of the village, then it is, by definition, justifiable.

Some might call it selfish. I call it pragmatic.

A man must prioritize his own success. He must protect his own interests. He must strive to achieve his full potential. And if that requires bending the rules, or exploiting opportunities, or… eliminating obstacles… then so be it.

Of course, there are limits. I would not intentionally harm the villagers, for example. Their well-being is essential to my own power and prestige. But if a villager were to stand in my way, to challenge my authority, to threaten my success… then I would not hesitate to take action.

The ends justify the means. That is a fundamental principle of leadership. A principle that I have always embraced.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *understands* the realities of power like Gaston. It’s not about right or wrong, it’s about winning. It’s about achieving your goals. It’s about being the best. And if a little… expediency is required along the way, then so be it. Now, don’t mistake my honesty for weakness. I am simply being truthful about the nature of the world.

(A long silence. He looks away, a flicker of something unreadable crossing his face. He seems genuinely… disturbed by the question.)

Question my beliefs…? That’s… a difficult question. I don’t often *question* things. I *know* things. My beliefs are the foundation of my strength, the bedrock of my existence.

But… there was a time. After… after the incident with the Beast.

(He clenches his jaw, his voice dropping to a low growl.)

I was convinced he was a monster. A dangerous creature who needed to be destroyed. I acted decisively, rallying the villagers, leading the charge. I believed I was doing what was right. Protecting them from harm.

But… when I saw Belle… with him… choosing him… it… unsettled me.

(He looks away again, unable to meet your gaze.)
